markdownRemark.html:
Picking my battles

I may be outing myself out too early, but despite being critical of both the tech industry and our capitalist society, I recently graduated from a master's program in human-computer interaction (HCI) and am still holding down a full time corporate tech job. Seeing the inherent white supremacy that is so deeply embedded in both academia and corporate tech is absolutely demoralizing. Yet, I stay because I have bills to pay. I have felt exhausted for years, and the exhaustion has become dehibilitating within the past few months. There is no way to sugarcoat that.

After some particularly tiresome experiences with racism in a recent project, I reached out to a friend who rightfully reminded me that simply being non-white does not necessarily qualify me to speak on issues of racism. Trying to justify my own (and other BIPOC's) existence(s) to white people is emotional labor that I did not have training, resources, or monetary compensation for.

To preserve my sanity, I pulled back (which got me typecasted as the "silent Asian woman"). When things got worse, I demanded boundaries (which got me typecasted as the "problematic woman of color"). Damned if I do, damned if I don't.

I am constantly inundated with white guilt. Even more recently, I found myself in a DEI (diversity, equity, & inclusion) roundtable in which the moderators wanted to split us into breakout rooms to discuss "actionable" things we could do to be more "inclusive." Frankly, I couldn't think of any way to "reform" our institution to be more inclusive, and I was frustrated that our diversity efforts were mirroring the white-centric anti-racism parroted in White Fragility (which, in my opinion, should be called "white narcissism" and has been critiqued by folks far more eloquent than me).???

My advice for other BIPOC in this position is this: pick your battles and do what you need to survive until you can leave. Your mere survival is resistance.
